PREFACE
This grammar has been written as a practical description of
one of the styles of modern Japanese whichis relatively restricted in use. It is based on a large number of official Japanese docu-

ments and communications; consequently, that use of this style is stressed rather than its use for scientific or artistic materials. In the schools of Japan it is taught only after the essentials of the colloquial have been mastered. We therefore presuppose a knowledge of Colloquial Japanese for users of this granmar, and have attempted to make our description and terminology correspond

to that of the grammars listed below. Various grammars of Colloquial Japanese are now readily accessible. Elementary Japanese for University Students by Serge Elisséeff and Edwin 0. Reischauer (Cambridge, 2nd ed., 1942) is an introduction especially to those forms of the colloquial found in literary texts. Elementary Japunese for College Students by the
same authors and Takehiko Yoshihashi (Cambridge, 1941) is more general in choice of vocabulary and texts, with greater emphasis

on practical and scientific vocabulary. Spoken Japanese by Bernard Bloch and Eleanor Harz Jordan (Washington, 1945) devotes more attention than the grammars mentioned above to analysis of the Janguage, but unlike them, teaches neither the kana nor the
character systems of writing. Grammars that may be used for

reference are: Modern Conversational Japanese by Joseph K. Yamagiwa (New York, 1942), especially for the examples; Handbook of Japanese Grammar by Ilarold G. Henderson (Boston, 1943), especially for the
full discussion of particles. Older grammars and other works on the language are listed in a convenient bibliography, 4 Selected
List of Books and Articles on Japan, compiled by Hugh Borton,
Serge Elisséeff, and Edwin 0. Reischauer (Washington, 1940), pp. 73-80. Of these, An Historical Grammar of Japanese by George B. Sansom (Oxford, 1928) gives an excellent historical study of
Japanese, especially the Classical Style. With the material in
one of the grammars listed above and in this grammar the reader should be able to read most texts in the Forma] Written Style. Kenkyusha’s New Japanese-English Dictionary, ed. by Yoshitaro
Takenobu (Amer. ed., Cambridge, 1942), will provide most of the
necessary lexicographical help, although the Durjiten of M. Ueda
(Amer. ed., Cambridge, 1942) may occasionally be necessary for an unusual word. To locate characters and character compounds, Beginners’ Dicttonary of Chinese-Japanese Characters by Arthur
Kose-Innes (Amer. ed., Cambridge, 1942) is usually adequate,
although Ueda’s Daijiten may again be necessary for rare characters
and compounds. We thank those who have helped us in writing this grammar by
their use of it and their suggestions for its improvement. [t
owes most to Serge Elisseeff and Edwin 0. Reischauer. They and

_ Pr | Be make no provision for /g zd b p/, for long consonants, for syl-
lables composed of consonant plus /y/, or for double vowels.
Various conventions for indicating these have been developed.
Examples illustrating these conventions will be listed in romanized kana syllables rather than in either Atragana or katakana char-

acters. In most texts writteninkana, /g 2 d b/ are indicated by means of kana characters of the ka column, so column, te column, and the ha column marked with two slant lines, called the ntigori sign,
placed at the upper righthand corner of the kana; /p/ is indicated
by means of the kana characters of the Ag column marked with a circle, called the han-nigorit sign. For example, ga in htragana
is written 9, gid , gue , balt”, po は は) , etc.; ga in katakana is written #” , barsv , pas * , etc. In some poetical
texts, inthe writing of laws prior to the occupation, and in texts dealing with religious matters, these diacritics are often omitted; han might there indicate /han/, /ban/, or /pan/; the reader 1s
expected to supply the correct reading.
Some archaic kana spellings have been retained in modern

Japanese, even though the pronunciation has changed. The most important such spellings are those used for common postpositions; thus/¥ (ha) is used to write the particle wa, ~ (he) to write , & (wo) to write o.
2.6 Changes that Occur in Compounds and Methods of
Indicating Sound Combinations in Kana
Shortcomings of the kana are especially noticeable in com- binations of consonant followed by /y/, in indicating doubled vowels, and in the writing of compounds, that 1s, words made up of

two or more lexical elements. When the kana syllabary was devised, such combinations apparently were not found inthe language; at any rate the methods of indicating them are awkward. To read kana with
ease one must know both the changes that sounds may undergo and the
methods of writing sound combinations. *
2.64 Voicing in Compounds
Syllables with nigort, that is voiced /k s t p/, are found in
simple Japanese words, e.g., go ‘five,’ but are especially common in the second elements of compounds. Many words which do not have
nigori when used alone have it 1n compounds, e.g., koku ‘country, ’
sangoku ‘three countries.’

*Since the occupation, efforts have been made toreform the methods of writing Japanese. An account of the attempted reforms in the kana and character methods of writing Japanese and a report on their success may Le found in “Reforms in the Language and Orthography of Newspapers in Japan,” Ly J. K. Yamagiwa, Journal of the American Oriental Society 68 (1948). 45-52.

2.7. Writing in Characters ,
Texts in the formal written style are usually written in a combination of characters and kana; most nouns, verbs, and adverbs
are written in characters; most particles and verb inflections are written in kana. The selection given above would be written as follows by this
system: 、 wv RRL a HOES APG
A wet $A OP
The majority of characters have more than one reading; the
choice of reading is determined by the meaning used in a specific
context and by convention. If a character has more than one on reading the choice of reading in any unknown compound may be
determined only by consulting a dictionary; if a character has more than one kun reading the choice of reading can usually be determined

from the kana which follow it. The common on readings of the character JF. are set and syd; 4. Hy 1s read seibutu ‘creature’ but 年 . 43 is read sy6toku ‘nature.’ Common kun readings of }¢ are umu ‘give birth,’ iktru ‘liye,’ naru ‘bear fruit,’ haeru ‘grow,’
nama ‘fresh’ andki ‘raw’; all may be distinguished by the following
kana, or its absence—umu is written 4A 4 , tkiru HAW , naru # と , haoeru H x we, nama % gz, kif.
The reading of any character may usually be determined without
question, and the meaning may be consulted in dictionaries.
Occasionally, however, the characters of a compound may be reversed,
and the resulting compound may not be listed in dictionaries. AO
‘action’ cannot be found in dictionaries, but k3dé ‘action’ is an accepted word. While the writing of texts in characters gives
rise to some difficulties, it has the merit of clearly distinguish-
ing the word in question from other possible homonyms.

I’; honkan ‘(this official) I,’ and so on. Zibun ‘oneself’ is a reflexive which can be used with any of the nouns mentioned above; it usually refers to the subject of the
sentence.
Kthd zibun no zyunbt の nasazarubekarazu, ‘Youmust make your own preparations.’
TOhS wa zibun no keikaku o zikkd sen to su. ‘We are on the
point of carrving out our own plan.’
The elements used in FWS demonstratives are the same as those
of the colloquial; in interrogatives, tzu is used rather than do.
In classical Japanese ko ‘this thing (close),’ so ‘that thing,
this thing (farther away),’ and g ‘that thing’ may be used alone
as nouns. In FWS they are generally compounded with other ele-
ments: with re when referring to things, with ko when referring to places, with t1,/ttt when referring to places or directions, and with no when used to modify nouns. These compounds are listed
below:
‘this...’ ‘this, that...’ ‘that...’ ‘which, what...’
‘... thing’ kore sore are‘kare  izure
‘... place’ koko soko asoko rzuko
‘... direction’  kotti sottt atti Lzutt
(adjectival) kono sono ano vzure no/dono
Téti ‘this place, the place in question,’ kuti ‘your place, there,’ dott ‘the same place’ are commonly used instead of koko, soko, asoko,
As in the colloquial kono, sono, and anomay stand for kore no,
sore no, are no as well as for koko no, soko no, asoko no; thus
sono syomotu may mean ‘his book’ as well as ‘that book.’ Other interrogatives are: dare tare ‘who,’ nant ‘what’ (nan in compounds, e.g., nanzt ‘what time’), ttu ‘when,’ naze ‘why.’
Allofthe interrogatives but naze are similarly modified in meaning
when followed by ka and mo; e.g., tare ka ‘someone,’ tare mo ‘any-
one; everyone.’ See also ka and mo in chapter 6. Japanese hasnorelative pronouns. Attributive clauses corres- pond to relative clauses of other languages. See 5.1B.
3.7 Numerals and Numerary Adjuncts
FWS uses the numeral system of colloquial Japanese. The kun numerals: Aitotu hutatu mittu yottu itutu muttu nanatu yattu kokonotu tO are relatively rare; the on numerals are given below.
There are no irregularities in the numeral patterns; numerals from
20 to 99 can be made on the pattern of those from 10 to 19, and

Conclusive tobu- isogu- yuku~ sumu- toru- mdsu- matu- kau-
(Attributive tobu- isogu- yuku- sumu- toru- mosu- matu- kau-)
Indefinite tobi- isogi- yuki- sumi- tori- most- mati- kat-
Imperfective toba- isoga- YUKO- suma- tora- mosa- mata- kawa-
Perfective tobe- isoge- yuke- sume- tore- mose- mate- kae-
Imperative tobe isoge yuke sume tore mose mate kae
Class 1 verbs have only four different stems; the conclusive
and attributive, like the perfective and imperative, are alike. The perfective and imperative stems differ in all other classes,

the conclusive and attributive in the fourth and fifth. The base of the first seven sub-classes remains unchanged regardless of the following vowel. (The changes in pronunciation in sub-classes 6 and 7 are non-phonemic; the variants of /S/ before /i/ and of /t/ before /u/ and /i/ are regular pronunciations of the /s/ and /t/ phonemes, see 2.2.) Verbs of sub-class 8, however, have a base ending in a consonant that is found only before /a/; the five stems ending in other vowels fail to show the /w/. Forms
in which the imperfective stem is used are: future kawan ‘will
buy,’ hypothetical kawaba ‘if ] should buy,’ and the negative kawazu ‘does not buy,’ causative kawasimu ‘makes buy,’ and passive kawaru ‘is bought’ with their further inflections.
For a list of verbs belonging to class ] see Appendix JI.
4,4B Classes 2 and 3
To classes 2 and 3 belong all verbs with base ending in a vowel and with conclusive and attributive forms alike. They differ
from each other only in the vowel of the base; verbs of class 2
have /i/, of class 3 /e/. Because of their similarity the two classes have been combined by some scholars into one class. The FWS conclusive form of class 2 and 3 verbs is like the
colloquial conclusive: FWS miru ‘see,’ colloq. miru; FWS keru ‘kick,’ collogq. keru. Very few verbs belong to these classes; all
non-compounds belonging to classes 2 and 3 have only two syllables
in the conclusive present. We shall list all of them, even though
some are used only in classical, not FWS, texts. All other verbs,
not of class 1, with colloquial conclusive ending in tru and eru belong to FWS classes 4 and 5.
Verbs belonging to class 2 are: Atru ‘dry,’ htru ‘sneeze,’
iru ‘shoot,’ tru ‘cast,’ tru ‘be,’ ktru ‘wear,’ miru ‘see,’ niru
‘resemble,’ and niru ‘boil’; examples of compounds with class 2
verbs as second members are: Aikiiru ‘command,’ kaerimtru ‘look
back,’ and kokoromiru ‘try.’ Only keru ‘kick’ belongs to class 3.
The old class 3 verb neru ‘sleep,’ or its classical variant tnu,
is not found in FWS.

4.17 Analytie Chart of Verb Forms
Chart 11 is an analytic table attempting to summarize all the data given on the previous pages. The stems are listed; likewise
all terminations.
The six ‘stems’ of all verb inflections have been arranged in
two groups according to usage; the first four may he used as free

forms, the last two are used only as stems. To use Chart. T] it is necessary to know which terminations may be added to any given stem; for example, the past form ukert cannot be made, even though this is not stated on the chart. Tf such
exceptions are known it ns clear which endings may be added to any glyen stem; conversely it may be determined to which stem any siven ending must be added. For example, given any perfective
stem, withclass 1 u-verbs, one of three endings may be added: -0g,
-rifru, or -do; with other u-verbs only one of two: -ba or -do.
Conversely given the ending -best, one may conclude that the pre- ceding stem must be the conclusive.
4.18 Order of Inflections

The order in which compound inflections are added is well established. Examples have been given after the various lists of forms made in the secondary inflections. The following chart is given to sum up:
1。 Stem (toru-, tori-, tora-, etc.)
2. Secondary conjugations in the following order:
a. causative b. passive
c. potential
d. desiderat ive
e. besi-form or mazt-form, (-besi may also follow the negative )
3. Negative.
4. Forms of the primary inflection (in 4.7).
Examples are: (1) tort- (4) kt he took’ (1) tora- (3) zari- (4) ki ‘he did not take.’
(1) tora- (2) stme- (3) zerr- (4) ki ‘he didn’t have ... take.’ (1) tora- (2a) srme- (2b) rare- (2d) tast ‘we want you to have ... take.’

Postpositions compounded with to, such as tomo and to tedomo, are also preceded by the conclusive. (See these in chapter 6.) The conclusive form, unlike the attributive, 1s never used as a noun,
5.4B Uses of the Attributive
The attributnve form may be used before nouns or postposit ions.
Tt. then andicates a subordinating relationship of a verb to the

noun or postposition, but does not define that relationship further. The relations vary widely, as illustrated below. When used before nouns, the attributive form may have as subject the word it medifies, e.g., kO8Sy¥d suru dathyosya ‘the representa- tives who are negotiating’ or ‘the negotiating representatives.’ Tt may have as object the word it modifies, e.g., hassd setaru syokuryohin ‘the provisions that we sent.’ Tt may indicate a loca- tion of the noun modified, e.g., kosvé seru hasyo ‘the place where they were neyotiating.’ 1 し may indicate the use to which the noun Is put, e.g., hogekr suru syagektho ‘the mortars with which we bombard.’ Ttmay indicate the type of action expressed in the noun, e.g., SBko の kentiku seru svudan ‘the wav in which he erected the warehouse.’ While these attributive constructions may seem to vary widely, their meaning rarely is unclear, because specific verbs and

nouns are limited an use by their meaning. Adsyo suru dathyosva can only be ‘agents who negotiate’ not ‘agents who are negotiated, ete.’ Of the various types of attributive relationships only the attributive preceding its object may need comment, for in Japanese this construction is relatively common. 1f one remembers that in
Japanese, subjects of verbs are usually persons, not personified inanimate objects, one will he able to analyze correctly such constructions; the phrase: ta@ho sitaru kaisya would mean ‘the
company which we notified,’ not ‘the company which notified us.’ It may be assumed that attributive forms of transitive verbs will,
unless preceded by an object followed by o, generally have the
word they precede as object: hiassd seru zappin ‘the goods which we sent,’ toritaru syudan ‘the measures which we took.’ As is clear
trom the examples, such attributives take the place of relative
clauses of English and ocher languages.
The interpretation of clauses ending in attributive verbs
lefore particles may be determined from the meaning of the particle.
For example, Sekitan o bathut stezarau ni tuki kotetu の kyokyG suru koto o ezu ‘Since we are unable to buy coal we cannot supply the
steel.’, or ‘We cannot buy coal; therefore we cannot supply the
steel.’ Aonnan arubeki mo ketkaku o zikkd subese ‘Although there
may be difficulties we shal] carry out the plan.’ The types of relationship expressed by any given postposition are discussed

5.2C Use of the Past Tense Forms
Past. tense forms are used to indicate that an action has been completed or that a state has existed in the past.
H6koku wa zyfibun nari ya situmon seri ‘He asked whether the
report was adequate.’
Tekt ga kyodai naru heiryoku の motte santi homen yoru ukai
sest tokoro... ‘The fact that the enemy has with a powerful force
detoured from the mountain area...’
Tegamit o uketari ‘We received the letter.’
...2tsyoku sitarisi datgisi... ‘the MP who resigned...’
Meiret op hassezarisi sy6kG... ‘The officer who had not issued the order...’
Taist o kiso sesimetari ‘They had the ambassador return to the Soviet Union.’
Zairyd o kOnyu sietarr ‘We were able to buy the material.’
Tatkyaku sioreru butar,.. ‘The units that were retreating...’
In most constructions the four past tenses may be used inter-

changeably. Past 4 is rare. Past 1 is made only from class 1 u- verbs and from su. Verbs that make both past ] and past 2 seem to show a contrast in use between them, a contrast that is found as well between past 2 and past 3. Past 1 and 3 may indicate that an action has been completed and that its effects are continuing: Sina hassé seri ‘We sent. the goods (and they are on their way).’
Past 2 may indicate that the action has been performed: Sina hasso
stgr ‘We sent the goods (and that’s that).’ [ts use would then be
limited to situations expressing action completed in the past. It
is doubtful whether this distinction 1s observed by many present- day writers of FWS, for other patterns denote completion of an action: e.g., Sina hassé zumi ‘We have sent (completed sending)
the goods.’ It is interesting, however, to note that only past 2
is used with Sit-verbs and the negative, that 1s, with verbs indicating state. The past of such verbs indicates a state that

the following sentences.
Ame huraba mitt warukarubes: ‘If it rains, the roads will be bad. ’
Ame hureba miti worust ‘When it rains, the roads are bad.’ or ‘Since it rained, the roads are bad.’ 。 . . or [If it rains, roads are had.’
Adgekt seba sy6ri o en ‘If we attack, we will win.’
hégeki sureba sySri o etari ‘Since we attacked, we won.’
Tenko huryé naraba syuppatu hukané narubesi ‘Tf the weather should be unfavorable, it will be impossible for us to leave.’
Tenko huryd nareba syuppatu hukand nari ‘Since the weather is unfavorable, it. ts impossible for us to leave.’
Tenkd huryd nareba syuppatu hukand naritke ‘Since the weather
was unfavorable, it was impossible for us to leave.’
The hypothetical has been lost in colloquial Japanese; its

uses have been taken over by the form corresponding to the EWS conditional. When writing IWS some authors confuse the two forms and use the conditional where proper usage would demand the hypothe tical.

Both the hypothetical and conditional are being replaced more and more by analytical constructions, especially in the past tense. Attributives followed by baai, nt otte wa, less commonly toki ua, replace the hypothetical; attributives followed by tokt, sai, or nt tukt replace the conditional. More conmon than syori seba ‘if
he should manage’ is syOrt suru baat ‘in case he should manage’ ;
more common than sydéri sureba ‘when/since he manages’ is SYOrr
suru toki ‘when he manages’ or syart suru ni tukt ‘since he
manages.’
5,3B The (se of the Concessive
The concessive is rarelv used. When found 1t may be trans- lated ‘although...’ as in kore wa motiron no koto naredomo...
‘although this is self-evident...’ For constructions that replace
the concessive form, see go and mo in the list of postpositions,
chapter 6.
5,30 The Imperative and Circumlocutions for [t
The inperative is rare, except in a rhetorical use. ...to SeYo ‘let us assume that...’; Aokoromt nt miyo ‘let us make a test.’
An imperative with this meaning may be made even from st-verhs, hayakare ‘let it be fast--though it be fast,’ but is rare outside
of poetry.

simple future, potentiality, obligation, to command; because of its variety of meaning the besi-form can be interpreted adequately
only in context. The various meanings are listed below with illustrations.
(A) Probability: ‘he probably will, we suppose he will...’
Bunka no do tyotyo takakarubesi ‘The degree of specialization
will probably become even greater.’
ITkkoku no bungaku td o tydsa sureba sono kuni no tokuset Oo hakken suru koto you narubest ‘When we examine such things as the
literature of a country it will probably be easy todiscover the
characteristics of that country.’
iorsy syuppan siubest ‘We should be able tosail next week.’
This use of best often corresponds to: ‘is to, are to.’
Taist raityd subesi ‘The ambassador is to come to Japan (we
suppose the ambassador will come to Japan).’
(B) Obligation: ‘ought to, must...’
Raigetumatu made toti gaikokuzin tydsa subesi ‘We must investigate the foreigners here by the end of next month.’
(C) Command: ‘must, are to...’
kono mizu o nomubekarazu ‘Do not. drink this water.’
(D) Potentiality: ‘can be, may...’
narubeku hayaku... ‘as fast ascan be, as fast as possible...’
(E) Promise: ‘will, intend to...’
Sassoku syokurydhin hassé subesi ‘We will send the foodstuffs
at once.’
For use of the negative 0esr-form to express obligation, see 5. 6B.
5.11 The Desiderative
The desiderative is used as inthe colloquial to express desire;
with transitive verbs it always takes an object followed by o. Dost wa Osaka e hikd ryokd sitasi ‘He would like to go by plane
to Osaka.’ The desiderative is used very commonly after verbs with
honorific meaning to indicate a request. A number of such forms
are listed in 5.3C; they are used in FWS to take the place of
colloquial ttadaku and morau expressions.

(see the on’s in 9.2C) and the second element denotes that oljec-
tive; such words are: myitn ‘enter a hospital’; &ttyd ‘return to Japan (of an official)’; raid ‘come to Furope.’ Examples are:
Suzukt san ua kitvotvii mart ‘Mr. Suzuki is back in Japan.’
(sosen wa ny@kGtyi nart ‘The freighter 1s in port.’
Jaist wa ratkydty& nart ‘The ambassador has arrived here in
Tokyo.’
5,12B The ARJ-Form Used to Indicate State
With transitive verbs a state of being, resulting from com- pletion of the action, is expressed by adding inflections of -art
to the indefinite stem.
Sekrtan no sirvG tikoku start ‘The quantity of coal has heen
reported.’
This form corresponds to the colloquial verb phrase of te-form
followed by forms of aru. In this form the direct object of the
transitive verb is made the subject of the verb and is followed hy
the postposition g@, wa, or none whatsoever. The present form
corresponds to a perfect passive in Fnglish, the past to a past
perfect passive: 7eg2mt kukvarctart ‘The letter had been written.’

ーーー ・ el 5. May indicate agent in passive constructions, but 』、 generally replaced by nt otte or nt yori. Sensuikan ni gekitin seraretart ‘It was sunk by a submarine.’

6. Before verbs meaning ‘make, change, become,’ etc. nz indicates that the word it follows describes the new state assumed by the subject. See the comparison oi nr and to given under to. Ayosan syugisya ni narert ‘He
became a communist.’ Adsikan wa taistkan ni seri ‘The
legation was made into an embassy.’

7. ‘To, for.’ After verbal on compounds and the indef- inite form of kun verbs nt indicates purpose when followed by verbs meaning ‘try, plan, come, go,’ etc. Compare the colloquial kai ni tku ‘go to buy.’ Genzyd izi nu doryoku siori ‘They are trying to maintain the status quo.’

8. ‘And.’ An extension ot the use of nt indicating neighboring location is its use to join nouns which have a close relationship. Take ni tora ‘bamboos with tigers’ (as an art subject); zGSSt ni sinbun ‘magazines and newspapers.’ This use 1s common in describing the
components of Chinese characters: aR Athen nv tukt, that is, a character consisting of a lefthand radical hi @ , and tuki 月 : 38, tutrhen ni nari, that is,
a character consisting of a lefthand radical tuti eZ ; and nari や 2 .

(after ‘In spite of, when.’ This use resembles that of verbs) colloquial no ni. The adversative meaning is often so weak that nt may merely mean ‘when.’ Toku nt trai seru nit hakkiri sitaru kavt6 o nasazariki ‘In spite of the fact that I made a special request, he did not give a definite reply.’ Honsi wa...nobetaru ni kare wa...to osyu seri ‘when IT said..., he replied that...’
nite 1. ‘By, through, by means of’ (same as colloquial de).
Ausya nite yuku ‘He will go by train,’
2. ‘In, at’ (place of action; often replaced by nt oite). Roma nite kaidan stort ‘They are conferring at Rome.’
Like colloquial de, nite is often used as the te-form of nari; nite, the verb, must be carefully distinguished
trom nite, the postposition.
no No is used to indicate a relationship between two
nouns or nominal phrases; the relationship may be possessive, attributive, or appositional.

tek. to AOsen ‘In combat with the enemy.’ Indefinite form
of on verb, without st; fourth adverbial modifier of togetaru, t = - spe : hikoki nite “In a plane.’ Place modifier; fifth adver- bial modifier of togetaru.
sOretu naru sensi o ‘A heroic death.’ Direct object, with adjectival modifier, of togetaru.
togetaru ‘Achieved.’ Verb going with Tanaka; attribu-
: tive, past of togu.
ni tuki ‘Since.’ [ndicates break in sentence, with
a slight causal relationship.
kibuin o site “(Have) the officials in vour bureau.’ Persons caused to perform action of causa- tive verb.
migt no omomuki の ‘The substance of the above.’ Direct object
of final verb.
kaku sinbun ni tarsi ‘To every newspaper.’ Indirect object, with
adjectival modifier, of final verb.
titi sesimeraretast ‘Please have...notifv...’ Final verb; con- clusive, present, desiderative, passive, causative of tuti su,

Translation: ‘Today at the front, Major General Jiro Tanaka, who last month was appointed divisional commander, while directing operations on the Indo-Burman border, died heroically in a plane in combat with the enemy. Please have the officials in your bureau report this to all newspapers.’
The following 1s a short example of an equational sentence. Migit hukand no も doi rydmatu hihuku t& no unsdsen nite Sapporo e no tumikae no ken wa tkaga nari va ‘How would it be to transfer by
freighter to Sapporo such things as food and clothing 1f the above 1s Impossible?’
In Ws, sentences tend to be long and complex; each sentence often comprises what wonld be a complete paragraph in English.
The most. important statement generally is reserved for the end,
and is preceded by subordinate or explanatory statements. Lisually,
even in the longest sentences, all the elements of the sentence
are grammatically interdependent; clauses are related one to another by the attrilutive clause construction or by postposi- tions following the verls.

8,2 Determination of Subject
When the subject is expressed it is almost invariably placed

at or near the beginning of the sentence. It is frequently followed by wa or equivalents, such as nt oite (wa) or to site wa, rarely in FWS by ga; where go would be used in the colloquial the subject has no particle following 1t~-colloquial hon ga aru is FWS hon arv.

Position at the beginning of the sentence is the surest clue in identifying the subject. The presence of wa or an equivalent, however, is also an indication that the word preceding 1s either the grammatical subject or at least the logical subject. of the
sentence. As a general rule, while the subject of the principal verb is
indicated by wa or an equivalent, subjects of verbs in subordinate clauses are indicated by ga or have no particle following them;
for example, Hydzi. wa tdtvaku sert but Taist wa rydzi tétyaku seru mune nobetart ‘The ambassador said that the consul had arrived.’ Ka does not necessarily indicate a grammatical subject; sometimes,
for purposes of emphasis, the object of the main verb may be placed
at the head of the sentence and followed by ge. In such sentences the sulject of the verb is usually left unexpressed. See the
second use of wa in chapter 6. When a subject. is present in the sentence or clause there is
little difficulty in identifying 1t。 The troublesome feature
about subjects in Japanese is that so frequently they are not expressed at all, or, more correctly, thes are nonexistent. This
is just as true in the written as in the colloquial style. One

One of the most important points to note in the usage of honorific forms is their function in connection with the desid- erative. When the desiderative is used after the passive form of

any verb, or after any word or form considered honorific, 1t means ‘T wish you to...’ or ‘Please...’; for example, AOsyO seraretasi ‘IT wish you to negotiate.’ or ‘Please negotiate.’ Aritasr too is polite and usually means ‘(Will you) please...’ On the other hand the simple desiderative means ‘TI wish to...’; for example, Aosy ひ
sitast ‘I (we) want to negotiate.’
In the colloquial, in the epistolary stvle known as s6rdbun,
and in FWS, ttasu ‘do’ is normally a humble verb; for example,
utasimasu, itast s6ré, and itasubesi all mean ‘we shall (do).’
When the desiderative of ttasuis used in FWS, however, it normally
means, ‘we would like you to (do), please (do).’ This use is
often made clear by the use of the preceding honorifics; for
example, gosdhu ainaru YO itasitasi ‘please send...’ Where there
are no indications in the context of honorific use tfasitasi may
mean ‘T want to do’; for example, Hontit yori yusyutu itasitasr ‘I want to export from here.’ Tamawaru/uketamawaru is a humble word meaning to ‘receive
(from a social superior).’ With the desiderative it means ‘T
should like to learn from you, please inform/send me’; for example, Saimoku uketamawaritast ‘Please send details.’
8.2C Determination of Subject by Directional Morgs
FWS frequently makes use of ‘directional words’ to indicate
the relationship between the writer and the actton described.
Terms indicating location like 7646 ‘this side’ for ‘I’ or ‘we,’
kthd ‘honorable side’ for ‘you’ are commonly used as pronouns:
see 3.6. Verb forms indicating a direction of motion toward or motion
away from ‘this side’ or ‘that side’ often help to determine the
subject constructions. For example, の 4% means ‘to go,’ rat oe
means ‘to come’; therefore 6h@ is ‘yoing to visit,’ rathé is
‘coming to visit.’ Sakuzitu Suzuki ravhd seru sav... can only
mean ‘Yesterday when Suzuki called on me...’ On the other hand
Sakuzitu Suzuki 6AO seru sat... can mean only ‘Yesterday when I
called on Suzuki...,’ unless Suzuki is a subordinate of the
writer and is therefore considered on his side.
Various extensions of this use of words like ‘come’ or ‘go’
will be found. One such is the use of kttaru and oku as second
members of verb compounds. 月 Aoku sikitarert (colloquial site kita) means ‘a report has been made in the direction of the
speaker, a report has come in.’ In some cases, however, 1t
can mean ‘I have just come from making a report.’ The context

If, however, the clause were tyugoku no ketzat zyotar nv kansuru an wa..., context might indicate that it means ‘the bil] concerning economic conditions in China.’ While context is the final determining factor in analyzing such constructions, the former type of construction 1s definitely the mere common. When various modifiers precede one word they areusually listed in the order of universal or general te partacular and of larger
unit to smaller unit. Japanese addresses gtve a convenient illustration; the largest geographical division is placed first, followed by successively smaller divisions, with the name of the
addressee last. For example:
Tokv6 st AvOhLast ku Marunoutt Nauka tyo 2 hantie Tanaka Ttird Tchiro Tanaka, %o. 20 Marunouchi Naka Street, Kyobashi Ward, Tokyo (city).
Aanagava ken Yokohama si \aku ku Benten dori “4 hantiy Tanaka
Zi.r6 Jiro Tanaka, No. 49 Benten Street, Naka Ward, Yokohama, Kanagawa Prefecture.
EE し ken Jaumanaka gun Aogd mura Gaza \issinmura Tanaka Saburé
Saburo Tanaka, Nisshimmura Section, Koga Village, Yamanaka District, Aichi Prefecture.
§.4 Apposttronal Constructions
Just as the Japanese prefer the ‘equational sentence’ to a direct statement, they often place words and phrases in apposition instead of using modifying construction. That is, the Japanese
say, ‘the countries of Furope, cach of them’ rather than ‘each
European country’; ‘those who are officials, the ones who returned
to their posts’ rather than ‘the officials who returned to their
posts.’ Some of the patterns are described below.
8,44 Serres of Words Joined by TO/NADOSBA
Frequently words describing specific objects followed by to (‘etc.’) stand in apposition to some wordor general classification following the to; for example, svodokuvaku télvd t& yukuhin...,

literally ‘disinfectants, vaccines, ete., medical supplies,’ that is, ‘medical supplies such as disinfectants and vaccines.’ TO can also connect clauses to the general word, as in the following example: Supein wa sensen suru va to patko mondutr... ‘diplomatic problems such as the question whether Spain wil] declare war...’ A similar use of ドコ > read as ra, is found in constructions such as the following; Yamada ra Domer tusin’in go mer... ‘Yamada
and others, Dome1 correspondents, 5 persons.’ The phrases stand
in apposition, and the phrase means: ‘five DD6mei correspondents consisting of Yamada and others,’ or better, ‘Yamada and four other Déme1 correspondents.’
S.4B ルナ SITE. MONG Gonstruettons
Words preceding ni site ‘being’ often stand in apposition with
mono in the clause which follows ni sete; for example, ttt nu Betziun nu site yvokuryii seraretaru mono..., literally ‘those being
Americans here, the ones who have been interned,’ that is, ‘the
Americans here who have been interned.’ The words preceding nt
site are 1n apposition to mono and could be substituted for mono to form a simpler construction; the above is equivalent to yokurya

seraretaru t6ti no Betzin. The only difference between the two phrases, if any, is that the mt site coustruction mav put more emphasis on the subject, setting it off somewhat in the manner of the particle wa. In this usage ni site differs from to stte which 1s used in a similar construction to mean ‘as, in the capacity of’; ni site, however, is the te-form of nari ‘he.’ Accordingly ni site and to site give entirely different meanings in the following clauses:
tekikokuzin ni site yokuryu seraretaru mono... ‘the enemy nationals
who have been interned’; tektkokuzin to site yokuryu seraretaru
mono... ‘those who have been interned as enemy nationals.’
&.5 Quotatrons
Determination of the speaker in sentences containing quotations
has been discussed in 8.2; other parts of quotation patterns are discussed here.
Quotations in Japanese are always inthe direct form; the words
of the speaker are usually reproduced, or they may be summarized.
This characteristic of Japanese quotations may be clearly illus-
trated by citing an example of a quotation before a verb meaning
‘deny, negate, etc.’ In Japanese one savs: MyGnitt syuppatu su to hiter seri (Literally, ‘tle denied, saving, “I will leave tomorrow.” *?) ‘He denied itand said that he would leave tomorrow.’
In this example and in similar uses, to corresponds to to itte, to
omotte and the like. For example, Avnnan nart to sinpat srtari ‘He worried, feeling that it was difficult.
8.54 QUuotutton Patterns
Since quotations are common in FWS it is useful to have
complete mastery over the patterns that occur. Quotations of
statements are commonly expressed in the pattern that is usual in
the colloquial: Janaka si wa...to nobetari ‘Mr. Tanaka said...’

Such pairs are so normal that Japanese lexicographers some- times assume that only one of any pair need be listed in a dictionary. Osamaru ‘to be paid’ is listed in Kenkyusha's dictionary; this is an intransitive verb of pattern (a), and a transitive verb osamu ‘to pay’ may be assumed. (Such a meaning is
listed under osameru ‘to rule over.’) On the pattern of ugoku/
ugokasu a transitive verb may be made from tomonau ‘to accompany,’
that is, tomonawasu ‘to make accompany.’ Sometimes the relationship between the two members of a pair
is obscured by the loss of a consonant before certain vowels. In
oeru ‘to make end’ the /w/ which is still found in owaru ‘to come to an end’ has been iost. This pair then fits pattern (a). In
turyasu ‘to spend’ the /y/ is preserved and in tutu (tureru) ‘to
be spent’ it is lost. Such pairs are rare, and in most verbs the
relationship between the pairs is apparent.
9.5 Verb Compounds
An important feature of Japanese word formation 1s the great number of verb compounds. In FWS these are not so frequent as in
the colloquial. Below are listed the verbs most likely to occur in such compounds. A number of verbs, usually transitive and intransitive pairs,
are used as second elements in such compounds with recurrent meanings. Some are used in functions very similar to prefixes in
. English; for example, kau ‘re-,’ as in kakikau ‘rewrite’; others
are similar to English prepositions; for example, komu ‘into,’ as in nagekomu ‘throw into.’ The most common such verbs are given
below with their meanings in compounds and with examples.

but generally there will be no inflections except those of soro itself, The conjugation of soro resembles first class u-verbs, but is irregular in that it lacks a separate form for the indefinite, for which the conclusive/attributive is used, and it has no past tense forms. Forms are:
Present concl./attr. の rO (kana: sahurahu)
Future . - sorawan (kana: sahur ahan) (Future is usually replaced by ...bekusGré)
Hypothetical sdrawaba (kana: sahurahaba)
Conditional soraeba (kana: sahuraheba)
Concessive sdraedomo (kana: sahurahedomo)
Te-form sordte (kana: sahurahute) (rare)
10,14 Substitutes for SU
Another characteristic of ES is that su in its active forms is rarely used to make verbs of on compounds; Serare is regularly
used, however, when a passive meaning 1s required. For first person, or objects related to the first person subject ttastsdro, from itasu ‘to do’ (compare colloquial rrosz-
masu), or more polite tukamaturiséré, from tukamaturu ‘to do,’ are used. Examples are:
Tokyo siten’in Suzuki Jtird gohdmon itasubekusédré ‘Mr. Ichiro Suzuki of our Tokyo branch will call on you.’
Hon-mondai kaiketu no tame zyibun doryoku tukamaturisdrd ‘We
have used all our efforts to settle this problem.’
For second person, or honorific third person, the following
verbs meaning ‘to do’ are generally used: nasareséro, from nasu; kudasaresdrd, from kudasaru; nasikudasaresérd; and very polite asobasareséro. Examples are:
Sakuzitu gorathd kudasaresdro ‘You were sc kind as to call (on
us) yesterday.’
flituyd no zyunbi o nasareorisdrd to zonzts679 ‘We believe you
are making (have made) the necessary preparations.’
Hon’an gokdryo asobasaresorawaba... ‘if you will carefully
consider this proposal...’
Kore ni tyut nasikudasares6ré ni tuki... ‘since you have given
careful attention to this matter...’
For third person subjects ttasisdro is generally used; examples
are:

10.3 Polite hords and Phrases in ES
ES uses with great frequency polite words or phrases that for the most part are merely ornamental and have little meaning. The
use of such words adds a polite or formal flavor to the text of
the letter, but the words have lost most of their specific polite
meaning. Itasu itself 1s apolite and humble word, but it is used in- |
discriminately as anequivalentof su; for example, Sono kekka Taiwan
Maru wa yaku zippunkan o hete tinbotu itasisdrd ‘As a result, the
Taiwan Maru sank in about ten minutes.’ Implications of polite-
ness would hardly be appropriate in such a sentence. The honorific go (0) is used very freely in ES: 1ts use is not
at all confined to an indication of second person or polite third
person. Verbs describing the writer’s own actions are frequently
preceded by go when they have some bearing on another person. Impersonal phrases may also be preceded by the honorific.
Stereotyped phrases commonly used in FS with little meaning
are:
mosubekusoré ‘T/we will (state that)...’ 4 7 修
mbsiagetakusorO ‘I/we will (state that)...’ ? Tk BAK

Even in business letters and less formal personal letters, where the introductory phrases may be omitted, an apology for omitting them is generally included. These polite phrases almost always mention the state of the weather and the addressee’s good health. The text is introduced by the words nobureba or stkareba, The closing compli-
ments usually consist of some phrase ‘bringing the foregoing to the favorable notice’ of the addressee. For examples of letters
in ES, with commentary, see B. H. Chamberlain, Moyit no Shirube,

APPENDIX ITI
THE JAPANESE FORMS OF BORROWINGS FROM ENGLISH

Many English words have been borrowed into Japanese since the middle of the nineteenth century. When such words are taken over into Japanese they regularly undergo great changes because the sound systems of Japanese and English differ markedly. These changes are stated below on the basis of the Japanese and English sound systems, not the spellings; for the substitutions are usually made on the basis of the spoken language, not the written—on the basis of sounds or sound-classes, not letters. The Japanese sound system was described in chapter 2. A few general rules given there apply to borrowings inte Japanese.

(1) Since Japanese does not admit any consonant clusters with the exceptionof consonant and y, all other clusters must be broken into series of consonant and vowel. Cambridge becomes Aenburizn, San Francisco San Hiuransisuko,
(2) All Japanese syllables end in a vowel or n; (internally in

a word, however, consonants may be doubled.) Boston becomes Bosuton, Truk Torakku. The vowel added to break up consonant clusters is u except after t and d; there o is used, in order to avoid the sound change. The Japanese form of rocket is rokketto,
of Poland Pérando.

(3) In some of the phonemes Japanese automatically makes sub- stitutions with the change in vowels; compare the three different pronunciations of the final consonant of the stem in: tetazu, tatitar, tatu. Such changes are made also in borrowings; touring becomes tiiringu, as if from ‘tsu-’; partisan becomes purutizan, as if from ‘parchi-.’ Roofing shows up as ruhingu, who as hu,
British pronunciation, not American, is usually the basis for borrowings; yacht is borrowed as yotto, tire as taiya. Treatment. of borrowings 1s illustrated below with examples listed according
to English phonemes. English consonantal phonemes are treated in three different
ways 1n Japanese. (1) The English phoneme may be taken over with

no substantial change; to this group belong /p b r/. (2) The English phoneme is not. changed before some vowels; to this group belong /tdk gf sz J2nmndj」w/. (3) The English phoneme 1s not found in Japanese; to this group belong /v 88 1/.
Group 1; consonant unchanged.
/p/ pin pin; pen pen; pipe patpu; portable potaburu; plunger
puranzya,; pure pyiia,
/b/ beam biimu; hale beeru; bus basu; box tbokkusu; boom bumu,
/r/ frequency hurtkuensti; resin rezin; rosin rozin; ruby rubl; prune puryun or puruun,
Group 2; consonant changed hefore some vowels.
/t/ unchanged before e a 0; table teeburu; shutter syatta; torch tétt. changed before t ¥; team (tumor tube tydlu. In some words,
an attempt is made to avoid this change by substituting an e for
L; putty is borrowed as pate, cantilever as kantewrevaa,
changed before u; touring tiiringu.
/d/ unchanged before e @ 0; data deeta or data; dust dasuto;
dome domu,
In borrowings with /d/ before other vowels ,d/ falls into the
z phoneme; dinghy zingt; duplex Zyupurekkusu.
/K/ unchanged except in a few words with a sound sequence as in camera; keel kitru; cable keebluru; cubic ky@bikku; coil kotru;
cushion kussyon. Before @ in borrowings with the English sequences found in carbon kaabon, coupling kappuringu た is unchanged; in
words like camera kyamera, however, y js often inserted after & to approximate the English front vowel. Caterpillar kyatapiraa;
capstan kyapusutan; calico kyartko, In canvas Ranbasu, cam kamu,
however, the y is not added.
/g/ unchanged; as with /k/ y is added in some words. Gig glgu; pauge geezt; gunwhale ganneru; golf goruhu, grey guree; but
gap gyappu. In the Tokvé dialect, intervocalic g is often pro- nounced [5_. This pronunciation varies from speaker to speaker,
and any borrowed word with intervocalic g may follow it.
/f/ remains before u; fuller huraa. Before other vowels one of two developments may take place: u may be added in Japanese,
and the Japanese bilabial f substituted for the English labio-
dental consonant; filament hutramento; ferry huerit; fiber huaibua;
foresail hudsuru; fuse Auyuzu, or u is not added, and /f/ under-
goes a change in pronunciation to other members of the A phoneme;
morphine moruhin; focal hdkaru; fork hoku.

No. 1 Ueda No. 80 4-] J Shime--To add (sum) up the figures; sum-total, amount; a
ream of 100 quires; a mark made on the back of a letter, in place
of a seal, and meaning ‘‘closed.” Shite—A form of the verb suru (used as a kana abbreviation).
KAN—Unit of weight equal to 8.26 pounds.
Although termed a kokuji by Ueda, this appears to be a kana
abbreviation based on the kana ジ shi and メ me.
4 No. 2 Ueda No. 89 4 - 3 Momme, me—Unit of weight equal to 3.75 grams. This consists of the katakana phonetic メ me enclosed within the
Chinese character x which is read MON, the two together clearly
suggesting the reading momme.
a No. 3 veda No. 115 5 - 8 も DENKI—Electricity.
Formed through the vertical synthesis of portions of the two Chinese characters ¥, ¥ , DENKI, meaning ‘electricity. ”
井 No. 4+ Ueda No. 137 7-2 Sono-—That, his, its.
This is probably an abbreviated form of 其 , having the same meaning; in ancient Chinese texts, the same contracted form 1s
to be found. It is not to be confused with Giles No. 1769 #F
CH’ IFN! which is an alternative form of Giles No. 17684} QItEN*
with the meanings: ‘‘Even, Jevel. To raise in both hands.”
AR No. 5 Ueda No. 14,906 9-4 Se, ot to—tlusband. Tsuma—Mate; husband; wife.
Combination of the ‘‘man” radical 4 and the common Chinese charac-
ter 大 read otto and otoko in Japanese.
AG No. 6 Not in Ueda 9- 5 JINZOSEKI—Concrete.
Formed through the horizontal amalgamation of the first and third
characters of the compound A_ 5G JINZOSEKI .
Aq, No. 7 Ueda No. 346 9-7 Omokage—Visage; traces, vestiges, shadow. Sugata—Figure, form, appearance. 、 The ‘‘man” radical combined with the character 沈 otdto or ototo, meaning ‘‘ younger brother.”
A No. 8 Ueda No. 347 9-7
Kuruma, JINRIKISHA—A small, two-wheeled carriage drawn by a
man; a man-power-cart.
